ceased to exist.

## Russian Civil War and Mongolia[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sino-
Soviet_relations&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Russian Civil War and
Mongolia")]

The [Beiyang government](/wiki/Beiyang_government "Beiyang government") in
north China joined the [Allied intervention in the Russian Civil
War](/wiki/Allied_intervention_in_the_Russian_Civil_War "Allied intervention
in the Russian Civil War"), sending forces to
[Siberia](/wiki/Siberian_Intervention "Siberian Intervention") and [North
Russia](/wiki/North_Russia_Campaign "North Russia Campaign") beginning in
1918.

[Mongolia](/wiki/Mongolia "Mongolia") and [Tuva](/wiki/Tuva "Tuva") became
contested territories. After being [occupied](/wiki/Occupation_of_Mongolia
"Occupation of Mongolia") by the Chinese General [Xu
Shuzheng](/wiki/Xu_Shuzheng "Xu Shuzheng") in 1919, they came under the sway
of the [Russian White Guard](/wiki/White_movement "White movement") General
turned independent warlord, [Ungern von
Sternberg](/wiki/Roman_Ungern_von_Sternberg "Roman Ungern von Sternberg") in
1920. [Soviet troops](/wiki/Red_Army "Red Army"), with support from
[Mongolian](/wiki/Mongols "Mongols")
[guerrillas](/wiki/Mongolian_People%27s_Party "Mongolian People's Party") led
by [Damdin Sükhbaatar](/wiki/Damdin_S%C3%BCkhbaatar "Damdin Sükhbaatar"),
defeated the White warlord and established a new pro-Soviet Mongolian [client
state](/wiki/Client_state "Client state"), which by 1924 became the [Mongolian
People's Republic](/wiki/Mongolian_People%27s_Republic "Mongolian People's
Republic").

## The KMT, the CCP, the Chinese Civil War and the establishment of diplomatic
relations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sino-
Soviet_relations&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: The KMT, the CCP, the
Chinese Civil War and the establishment of diplomatic relations")]

In 1921 the Soviet Union began supporting the [Kuomintang](/wiki/Kuomintang
"Kuomintang") (KMT), and in 1923 the [Comintern](/wiki/Comintern "Comintern")
instructed the [Chinese Communist Party](/wiki/Communist_Party_of_China
"Communist Party of China") (commonly abbreviated as CCP) to sign a military
treaty with the KMT. On May 31, 1924, the two governments signed an agreement
to establish diplomatic relations, while the Soviet government renounced in
that agreement all privileges granted to the Tsarist government in China.[1]
But in 1926 KMT [leader](/wiki/Leader "Leader") [Chiang Kai-
shek](/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek "Chiang Kai-shek") abruptly dismissed his Soviet
advisers and imposed restrictions on CCP participation in the government. By
1927, after the conclusion of the [Northern
Expedition](/wiki/Northern_Expedition_\(1926%E2%80%931927\) "Northern
Expedition \(1926–1927\)"), Chiang purged the CCP from the KMT-CCP alliance,
resulting in the [Chinese Civil War](/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War "Chinese Civil
War") which would last until 1949, a few months after the proclamation of the
[People's Republic of China](/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_China "People's
Republic of China"), led by [Mao Zedong](/wiki/Mao_Zedong "Mao Zedong").
During the war the Soviets gave some support to the CCP, which in 1934
suffered a crushing blow when the KMT brought an end to the [Chinese Soviet
Republic](/wiki/Jiangxi_Soviet "Jiangxi Soviet"), thus causing the CCP's [Long
March](/wiki/Long_March "Long March") from [Shaanxi](/wiki/Shaanxi "Shaanxi").
The Soviet Union tried and failed in an attempt to make the[_[clarification
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please clarify")_]
[Hui](/wiki/Hui_people "Hui people") hostile to China.[2]

## Sino-Soviet conflict, 1929[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sino-
Soviet_relations&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Sino-Soviet conflict,
1929")]

Main article: [Sino-Soviet conflict (1929)](/wiki/Sino-
Soviet_conflict_\(1929\) "Sino-Soviet conflict \(1929\)")

The Sino-Soviet conflict of 1929 was a minor armed conflict between the Soviet
Union and the Republic of China over the [Manchurian](/wiki/Manchuria
"Manchuria") [Chinese Eastern Railway](/wiki/Chinese_Eastern_Railway "Chinese
Eastern Railway"). The Chinese seized the Manchurian Chinese Eastern Railway
in 1929, swift Soviet military intervention quickly put an end to the crisis
and forced the Chinese to accept restoration of joint Soviet-Chinese
administration of the railway.

## Soviet Invasion of Xinjiang[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sino-
Soviet_relations&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Soviet Invasion of
Xinjiang")]

Main article: [Soviet Invasion of Xinjiang](/wiki/Soviet_Invasion_of_Xinjiang
"Soviet Invasion of Xinjiang")

In 1934 the Republic of China [36th Division (National Revolutionary
Army)](/wiki/36th_Division_\(National_Revolutionary_Army\) "36th Division
\(National Revolutionary Army\)"), which was composed of Muslims, severely
mauled the Soviet Union [Red Army](/wiki/Red_Army "Red Army") and their [White
Russian](/wiki/White_movement "White movement") allies when the Soviets
attempted to seize Xinjiang.

Main article: [Xinjiang War (1937)](/wiki/Xinjiang_War_\(1937\) "Xinjiang War

The Soviet Union intervened again in Xinjiang in 1937.

## Second Sino-Japanese War and World War II[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sino-
Soviet_relations&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Second Sino-Japanese War
and World War II")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Wuhan-Soviet-
Aviators-Tomb-0175.jpg/220px-Wuhan-Soviet-Aviators-
Tomb-0175.jpg)](/wiki/File:Wuhan-Soviet-Aviators-Tomb-0175.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Wuhan-Soviet-Aviators-Tomb-0175.jpg "Enlarge")

Monument to the [Soviet Volunteer Airmen](/wiki/Soviet_Volunteer_Group "Soviet
Volunteer Group") who died in defense of China from Japanese invaders. The
unit was based in Wuhan in 1938

In 1931, [Japan](/wiki/Empire_of_Japan "Empire of Japan") invaded
[Manchuria](/wiki/Manchuria "Manchuria") and created the [puppet
state](/wiki/Puppet_state "Puppet state") of [Manchukuo](/wiki/Manchukuo
"Manchukuo") (1932), which signaled the beginning of the [Second Sino-Japanese
War](/wiki/Second_Sino-Japanese_War "Second Sino-Japanese War"). In 1937, a
month after the [Marco Polo Bridge Incident](/wiki/Marco_Polo_Bridge_Incident
"Marco Polo Bridge Incident"), the Soviet Union established a [non-aggression
pact](/wiki/Sino-Soviet_Non-Aggression_Pact "Sino-Soviet Non-Aggression Pact")
with the Republic of China. During the [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II
"World War II") period, the two countries suffered more losses than any other
country, with China (in the [Second Sino-Japanese war](/wiki/Second_Sino-
Japanese_war "Second Sino-Japanese war")) losing about 30 million people and
the Soviet Union 26 million.

## Joint victory over Imperial Japan[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sino-
Soviet_relations&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Joint victory over
Imperial Japan")]

On August 8, 1945, three months after [Nazi Germany](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi
Germany") surrendered, and on the week of the [American](/wiki/United_States
"United States") [Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and
Nagasaki](/wiki/Atomic_bombings_of_Hiroshima_and_Nagasaki "Atomic bombings of
Hiroshima and Nagasaki"), the Soviet Union launched the [invasion of
Manchuria](/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria "Soviet invasion of Manchuria"),
a massive military operation mobilizing 1.5 million soldiers against one
million [Kwantung Army](/wiki/Kwantung_Army "Kwantung Army") troops, the last
remaining [Japanese military](/wiki/Imperial_Japanese_Army "Imperial Japanese
Army") presence. Soviet forces won a decisive victory while the Kwantung
suffered massive casualties, with 700,000 having surrendered. The Soviet Union
distributed some of the weapons of the captured Kwantung Army to the CCP, who
were still battling the KMT in the Chinese Civil War.

## Ili Rebellion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sino-
Soviet_relations&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Ili Rebellion")]

Main article: [Ili Rebellion](/wiki/Ili_Rebellion "Ili Rebellion")

While the [Republic of China](/wiki/Republic_of_China "Republic of China") was
concentrating on the [Second Sino-Japanese War](/wiki/Second_Sino-Japanese_War
"Second Sino-Japanese War"), the [USSR](/wiki/USSR "USSR") supported
[Uyghur](/wiki/Uyghur_people "Uyghur people") nationalists in their uprise in
[Xinjiang](/wiki/Xinjiang "Xinjiang") and set up [Second East Turkestan
Republic](/wiki/Second_East_Turkestan_Republic "Second East Turkestan
Republic") against [Kuomintang](/wiki/Kuomintang "Kuomintang"). After the
[Chinese Communist Party](/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party "Chinese Communist
Party") defeated Kuomintang in 1949, USSR terminated support for the Second
East Turkestan Republic.

The Soviets tried to spread anti-Chinese propaganda among minorities in
Xinjiang, but this backfired when Uyghur mobs attacked [White
Russians](/wiki/White_movement "White movement") and called for them to be
expelled from Xinjiang.[3]

## Chinese Civil War and the People's Republic of
China[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sino-Soviet_relations&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Chinese Civil War and the People's Republic of China")]

After 1946, the CCP was increasingly successful in the Civil War. On October
1, 1949, the People's Republic of China was proclaimed by Mao Zedong, and by
May 1950 the KMT had been expelled from [Mainland China](/wiki/Mainland_China
"Mainland China"), remaining in control of [Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan "Taiwan").
With the creation of the People's Republic of China, the supreme political
authority in the two countries became centred in two communist parties, both
espousing revolutionary, [Marxist–Leninist](/wiki/Marxism%E2%80%93Leninism
"Marxism–Leninism") ideology: the Communist Party of China and the [Communist
Party of the Soviet Union](/wiki/Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union
"Communist Party of the Soviet Union").

After the establishment of the People's Republic of China, a sensitive issue
which influenced the Sino-Soviet relationship emerged. As a condition of
fighting the [Kwantung Army](/wiki/Kwantung_Army "Kwantung Army") at the end
of the Second World War, the Soviet Union received usage rights of the [China
Far East Railway](/wiki/China_Far_East_Railway "China Far East Railway"), the
[South Manchuria Railway](/wiki/South_Manchuria_Railway "South Manchuria
Railway"), [Lushun](/wiki/L%C3%BCshunkou_District "Lüshunkou District") (also
known as Port Arthur) and [Dalian](/wiki/Dalian "Dalian"). These privileges
were significant in the Asian strategies of the Soviet Union because Port
Arthur and Dalian were ice-free ports for the Soviet Navy, and the China Far
East Railway and the South Manchuria Railway were the essential arterial
communications which connected Siberia to Port Arthur and Dalian. As [Mao
Zedong](/wiki/Mao_Zedong "Mao Zedong") thought that the usage rights of the
[Chinese Eastern Railway](/wiki/Return_of_the_Chinese_Eastern_Railway "Return
of the Chinese Eastern Railway"), the South Manchuria Railway, the Port Arthur
and Dalian were part of Chinese state sovereignty, he required the Soviet
Union to return these interests to China, and this was a crucial part of the
[Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship](/wiki/Sino-Soviet_Treaty_of_Friendship
"Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship"). [Joseph Stalin](/wiki/Joseph_Stalin
"Joseph Stalin") initially refused this treaty, but finally made a great
concession, and agreed with this treaty under the various stresses of the
period.[4]

Since the Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship resulted in the Soviet Union losing
its naval bases in Port Arthur and Dalian, the issue that Stalin had to face
was to find a new ice-free port as a Soviet naval base. This issue motivated
Stalin's support for allowing [Kim Il-Sung](/wiki/Kim_Il-Sung "Kim Il-Sung")
to launch the [Korean War](/wiki/Korean_War "Korean War").[4] However, both
Kim Il-Sung and Stalin did not consider that the United States would intervene
into that war immediately, if at all. Kim Il-Sung could not sustain the attack
against the US Army. When Kim Il-Sung required military assistance from the
Soviet Union and China, Mao agreed to send Chinese troops, but asked the
Soviet Air Force to provide air cover. As the two leaders distrusted each
other, Stalin agreed with sending Chinese troops to Korea, but refused to
provide air cover.[5] Since without the air cover from the Soviet Union, Mao
once considered that China did not send troops into Korea, and Stalin at one
time decided to give up the Korea Peninsula.[5] After much cogitation, Mao
solely sent Chinese troops into Korea on 19 October 1950 under an extremely
hard Chinese economic and military situation. This activity ultimately changed
the Sino-Soviet relationship. After 12 days of Chinese troops entering the
war, Stalin allowed the Soviet Air Force to provide air cover, and supported
more aid to China.[5] Mao sending Chinese troops to take part in the [Korean
War](/wiki/Korean_War "Korean War") was followed by large-scale economic and
military cooperation between China and the Soviet Union, and the friendly
relationship of the two countries changed from titular to virtual. In one less
known example of the Sino-Soviet military cooperation, in April–June 1952 a
group of Soviet [Tupolev Tu-4](/wiki/Tupolev_Tu-4 "Tupolev Tu-4") aircraft
were based in Beijing to perform reconnaissance missions on American fusion
bomb tests in the Pacific.[6]

## Sino-Soviet split[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sino-
Soviet_relations&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Sino-Soviet split")]

Main article: [Sino-Soviet split](/wiki/Sino-Soviet_split "Sino-Soviet split")

Further information: [Sino-Soviet relations during the Brezhnev
Era](/wiki/History_of_the_Soviet_Union_\(1964%E2%80%931982\)#People's_Republic_of_China
"History of the Soviet Union \(1964–1982\)")

Thus, in the immediate years after the PRC was proclaimed, the Soviet Union
became its closest ally. Soviet design, equipment and skilled labour was set
out to help [industrialize](/wiki/Industrialisation "Industrialisation") and
[modernize](/wiki/Modernization "Modernization") the PRC. But the extent of
actual support, while not insignificant, fell well below Chinese expectations.
In the 1960s, relations became deeply strained following the [Sino-Soviet
Split](/wiki/Sino-Soviet_Split "Sino-Soviet Split"), culminating in the [Sino-
Soviet border conflict](/wiki/Sino-Soviet_border_conflict "Sino-Soviet border
conflict") in 1969. Increasingly, the PRC began to consider the Soviet Union,
which it viewed as [Social imperialist](/wiki/Social-imperialism "Social-
imperialism"), as the greatest threat it faced. In turn, overtures were made
between the PRC and the US, such as in the [Ping Pong
Diplomacy](/wiki/Ping_Pong_Diplomacy "Ping Pong Diplomacy") and the [1972
Nixon visit to China](/wiki/1972_Nixon_visit_to_China "1972 Nixon visit to
China").

The Soviet Union had encouraged [Uyghurs](/wiki/Uyghur_people "Uyghur people")
to rebel against China.[7]

## Post-Mao era and stabilizing relations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sino-
Soviet_relations&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Post-Mao era and
stabilizing relations")]

In 1976, Mao died, and in 1978, the [Gang of Four](/wiki/Gang_of_Four "Gang of
Four") were overthrown by [Deng Xiaoping](/wiki/Deng_Xiaoping "Deng
Xiaoping"), who was to soon implement pro-market [economic
reform](/wiki/Chinese_economic_reform "Chinese economic reform"). With the PRC
no longer espousing the [anti-revisionist](/wiki/Anti-revisionist "Anti-
revisionist") notion of the [antagonistic
contradiction](/wiki/Antagonistic_contradiction "Antagonistic contradiction")
between classes, relations between the two countries became gradually
normalized. In 1979, however, the PRC launched the [Sino-Vietnamese
War](/wiki/Sino-Vietnamese_War "Sino-Vietnamese War"), a failed invasion of
[Vietnam](/wiki/Vietnam "Vietnam") (which had, after a period of ambivalence,
sided with the Soviet Union) in response to the [Vietnamese invasion of
Cambodia](/wiki/Vietnamese_invasion_of_Cambodia "Vietnamese invasion of
Cambodia") which overthrew the China-backed [Khmer Rouge](/wiki/Khmer_Rouge
"Khmer Rouge") from power.

During the Sino-Soviet split, strained relations between China and the Soviet
Union resulted in strained relations between China and the [pro-Soviet Afghan
communist regime](/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_Afghanistan "Democratic
Republic of Afghanistan"). China and [Afghanistan](/wiki/Afghanistan
"Afghanistan") had neutral relations with each other during the rule of [King
Zahir Shah](/wiki/Mohammed_Zahir_Shah "Mohammed Zahir Shah"). When the pro-
Soviet Afghan communists seized power in Afghanistan in 1978, relations
between China and the Afghan communists quickly turned hostile. The Afghan
pro-Soviet communists supported the Vietnamese during the Sino-Vietnamese War
and blamed China for supporting Afghan anti-communist militants. China
responded to the [Soviet invasion of
Afghanistan](/wiki/Soviet_war_in_Afghanistan "Soviet war in Afghanistan") by
supporting the Afghan [Mujahideen](/wiki/Mujahideen "Mujahideen") and ramping
up their military presence near Afghanistan in Xinjiang. China acquired
military equipment from the United States to defend itself from Soviet
attack.[8]

China moved its training camps for the Mujahideen from Pakistan into China
itself. Hundreds of millions worth of anti-aircraft missiles, rocket launchers
and machine guns were given to the Mujahideen by the Chinese. Chinese military
advisors and army troops were present with the Mujahideen during training.[9]

Even though Soviet leader [Mikhail Gorbachev](/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev "Mikhail
Gorbachev") went on to criticize the post-Maoist CCP when it allowed for PRC
millionaires as having lost the [socialist](/wiki/Socialism "Socialism") path,
with the dissolution of the Soviet Union in the late 1980s and early 1990s,
the Soviet Union itself turned to [privatization](/wiki/Privatization
"Privatization").

## Dissolution of the Soviet Union[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Sino-
Soviet_relations&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Dissolution of the
Soviet Union")]

Unlike that of the PRC, this was a much more extreme, highly unregulated form
of privatization which resulted in massive losses to foreign speculators,
near-anarchical conditions and economic collapse. Thus, in the post-[Cold
War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War") period, while the Soviet Union remained vastly
more developed (economically and militarily), in a systemic and deep way
(_i.e._ , the PRC in 1949 was less industrialized than Russia in 1914), the
PRC emerged in a far more favourable and stable financial position. While the
severe Soviet shortage of capital was new, Chinese economic and military
underdevelopment was not. Nor was the PRC's desperate and ever-growing need
for mineral resources, especially [petroleum](/wiki/Petroleum "Petroleum")
[fuel](/wiki/Fuel "Fuel"), which the Soviet Union held in abundance in such
Asiatic regions as western [Siberia](/wiki/Siberia "Siberia").

See also: [Sino-Russian relations since 1991](/wiki/Sino-
Russian_relations_since_1991 "Sino-Russian relations since 1991") and
[Russia–Taiwan relations](/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Taiwan_relations "Russia–Taiwan
relations")
